Award.AwardTitle: Integrated Analytical Laboratory and Specialized Storage Renovation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the last 40 years, the Center for Coastal Studies (CCS) on outer Cape Cod, Massachusetts has advanced understanding of marine and coastal ecosystems, including: the biology of endangered species; the impacts of pollution on productive embayments; the effects of sea level rise on coastal resources and development; and the impacts of a changing ecosystem on marine mammals and fisheries. This award provides funds to expand research capability through the creation of a new Integrated Analytical Laboratory to facilitate research and opportunities for collaboration. Facilities for sediment analysis will help scientists understand complex coastal processes and help to guide adaptation and coastal resiliency actions that coastal communities must make. Such research is vital in light of the fact that sea levels are rising more dramatically in the northeast Atlantic than almost anywhere else in the world. Data from long-term population biology and ecology studies provide an invaluable foundation for assessing climate change impacts over the past 30 years and projecting into the future. They are particularly essential for understanding the remaining population of the endangered North Atlantic right whales that feed and nurse their young along the heavily industrialized and developed shore of eastern Massachusetts.

The improvements will more than triple the size of current laboratory space, and expand opportunities for collaboration with other scientific and academic institutions. The new laboratory will consist of facilities for water quality analysis, biological sample analysis and sediment analysis. Expanded laboratory capacity for water quality analysis will be essential in helping the region implement its EPA 208 Water Quality plan and remedy issues of nitrogen pollution in Cape Cod?s bays, inlets and harbors. The new laboratory facilities will also protect sensitive research archives generated by the Center?s multi-decade history of marine mammal research. The improved facilities will increase opportunities for graduate students, interns and apprentices, and enhance CCS?s unique ability and opportunity to interact with the public, thanks to its prominence in environmental education and outreach in a popular tourist destination. CCS?s STEM-based school programs, more than 100 annual public programs, public kiosk and Marine Discovery Center, and other outreach directly impacts nearly 20,000 people of all ages each year. The products of research will also help resource managers to better protect threatened and endangered environments and species. For more information about the Center for Coastal Studies, please visit the website at: http://coastalstudies.org/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF funding allowed the Center for Coastal Studies to expand its scientific capacity and opportunity for collaboration with the creation of a new Integrated Analytical Laboratory. 

Expanded research capability is furthering the important role the Center plays in coastal and marine science, providing the accurate science needed to address issues of strong societal concern and impact. This includes helping to guide coastal adaptation and resiliency actions for communities as sea level rises, and helping to protect clean coastal waters through the implementation of the region's EPA 208 water quality plan.  Other areas of focus include the creation of marine protected areas; working to understand and protect some of the world's most endangered species of whales; creation of an international whale disentanglement network; marine fisheries research (including creation of sustainable aquaculture); environmental assessments for offshore renewable energy programs; and habitat assessment.

The Center has a multi-decade commitment to training the next generation of scientists. Graduate and undergraduate students, interns, apprentices and community volunteers have already begun working in the new laboratory space, and its creation will greatly benefit the role we can play in this area.

The Center's previous lab space was limited to 400 square feet, with instrumentation and storage in different locations throughout the building.  This made for  inefficient and inadequate working conditions. In addition, a great deal of work could not be done in-house. 

The completed project created an entirely new upgraded laboratory,  more than tripled in size laboratory space, added needed equipment and specialized storage, and increased work space for visiting scientists, technicians and students. It also upgraded energy efficiency, environmental air quality, security, and safety. 

An example of new equipment is a chemical fume hood required for work with acids, solvents and bases. A traditional fume hood would require ducting the chemical fumes outside, and also require removing part of the solar array on the roof.  Instead, CCS installed a state-of-the-art  Labconco Protector Airo filtered fume hood.The new system can safely handle chemicals while returning clean filtered air back into the lab. Additional costly make-up air is not required, and there is no hazardous hood exhaust system on the roof.  This allowed the solar array to stay in place.  New climate control measures inside the lab also direct air flow away from locations that require minimum dust and other contamination. 

In addition, the new equipment and facilities allow the Center to do work in-house that previously required expensive off-site analysis. Not only does this make the organization's work more cost-effective, it also creates a facility in the relatively remote tip of Cape Cod where such work can take place.  For instance, the new capacity will benefit the Center's collaborators from the National Park Service to conduct sample analysis for a large salt marsh restoration project. 

The Center for Coastal Studies is very grateful for the support of the National Science Foundation in creating this important new resource for our region.
